8.text:
Hello. I’m Lizi, and welcome to this, the
third of CADARN’s series of kit videos.

13.text:
In this video, I'm going to be looking at the sound
equipment that CADARN provides its partners,

18.text:
everything from this Podcaster
microphone to this audio recorder.

22.text:
During the course of the video, I’m also
going to touch upon some of the things

26.text:
you need to think about when you’re recording
your sound to get the best results.

30.text:
To help you navigate this video,
we’ve added chapter buttons,

33.text:
so if you want to review something
or if you want to skip ahead,

36.text:
just click on some of the
buttons here beside me.

39.text:
So let's take a look at the core
equipment that we're going to cover.

43.text:
We'll start off by taking a look at what's
probably our best microphone, the RØDE NTG2,

49.text:
which is a directional mic,
otherwise known as a shotgun.

53.text:
Then we're going to look at this
lapel mic, the RØDE Lavalier.

57.text:
Next we'll take a look at the RØDE VideoMic Pro,
which is designed to work with a DSLR camera.

63.text: Next up is the Zoom H2n,

65.text:
which is an all-in-one portable recording
device with its own built-in microphones.

71.text:
Finally, we're going to talk
about the RØDE Podcaster,

74.text:
which is designed to record
directly onto a computer.

77.text:
So let's get started
with the RØDE NTG2.

80.text:
I'm just going to get
everything else off the table.

86.text:
Now, this is a directional
mic, also known as a shotgun.

90.text:
It's a good microphone to use with
the JVC HM150, which I've got here.

98.text:
Shotgun mics are very sensitive and have
what’s called a super cardioid polar pattern.

104.text:
Polar patterns are a visual way of understanding
which direction a mic is sensitive to,

109.text:
in other words, where it picks
up sound and where it doesn’t.

113.text:
As you can see from this diagram, super
cardioid is a narrow-focused pattern

117.text:
that targets sound directly in front of the
microphone, and rejects it from the side,

122.text:
just like a shotgun, shooting
in one focused direction.

126.text:
This is really useful, because it means you
can focus on specific sources of sound.

131.text:
The directional nature of shotguns make
them the go-to mic for video production,

135.text:
because they act just like a camera’s
lens, pointing in one direction.

139.text:
Shotguns are also useful if you want
to keep your microphone out of shot.

143.text:
One thing you have to remember with
this mic is it can't be handheld.

146.text:
If you do touch it, you’re going to get
a nasty rustling sound, like this…

150.text:
Now obviously this mic isn't plugged
in, but that's the magic of editing.

155.text:
You want to avoid that kind of noise at all
cost, because it will ruin your recording.

159.text:
What you need to do to avoid handling
noise is put the microphone on a mount.

163.text:
For instance, you could use an on-camera
mount like this one on the JVC.

167.text:
And I'll just show you
quickly how to do that.

170.text:
Put it in, close it up.
There you go.

175.text:
Make sure it's nice and tight so that
the microphone doesn't wobble around.

180.text:
Now you don't have to touch the mic, and the
little rubber pads inside the mount mean that

185.text:
it's not going to pick up any handling noise
when you're operating the camera either.

192.text:
of course the next thing you have to
do is connect it up to your camera.

195.text:
The NTG2, like most professional
microphones, connects using an XLR cable,

201.text:
and in this situation, you're going to need
an extra short one, like this one here.

207.text:
Now, you can always tell an XLR
cable by these three-pin plugs,

212.text:
and what you do is you take the female end, and
you stick it in to the end of your microphone.

222.text:
Then you take the other end and you plug
it into the XLR input on your camera.

229.text:
There you go, you're
all connected up.

232.text:
This set-up is great
if you're by yourself

234.text:
and you're having to move around
a lot while you're shooting.

236.text:
It's going to give you a natural sound with an
acceptable level of focus on your audio subject.

241.text:
However, you are limited
by your shooting distance,

243.text:
and you're not going to be able to get the mic
closer in for a more focused sound recording.

249.text:
The other thing you can do is mount the
microphone on a pistol grip, like this one.

256.text:
Now, a pistol grip does an even better job at
isolating the microphone from handling noise,

261.text:
thanks to this rubber suspension
cradle, also known as a shock-mount.

266.text:
Let me just show you how to put the
microphone into the pistol grip.

270.text:
I'll take it out of here,
and take the cable off.

274.text:
You can't put it into the pistol
grip with the cable attached.

277.text:
And it slides in like this… It's
actually pretty hard to do.

282.text:
Just push it in, don't worry too much.
There you go.

286.text:
Now you can see why it's called a pistol
grip, because it looks like a gun.

290.text:
Once the microphone's in, you can adjust
this head using this locking lever here.

295.text: I'll just undo it for you.

297.text:
There you go. I'm going to put it up.
Lock it down.

302.text:
And make sure this little knob is tight
so that it doesn’t wobble around.

305.text:
With this pistol grip, you can use the NTG2
as a handheld interview mic, like this.

314.text:
You can also attach it to a boom
pole, like the one I've got here.

321.text:
Using a boom pole allows you to get your
shotgun closer to the source of your sound,

325.text:
and it also allows you to point it at a specific
direction, and change that direction responsively.

331.text:
So for instance, if you're
recording two people talking,

334.text:
you can get your mic and point it to one
person first, and then the next person,

341.text:
A boom pole certainly
adds production value,

343.text:
but you do need an extra person
on your crew to operate it.

347.text:
A boom operator is very useful, because
they also often act as a soundman,

352.text:
taking care of every aspect of your sound
recording, like monitoring and levels.

356.text:
This is great, because it allows your
cameraman to focus only on the visuals.

361.text:
But using a boom pole isn't as easy as it looks,
so I'm just going to talk a bit more about it.

366.text:
To attach the pistol grip to the boom pole, what
you need to do is attach the end of the grip…

371.text:
…here you can see, the screw…
to the end of the pole.

377.text:
Let's do that. Make sure
it's as tight as possible.

382.text:
When you've got it attached, you can extend
the pole by loosening these rings here.

390.text:
Extending it out… Then, when you've got it
the length you want, you tighten it up.

395.text:
Grip there. Loosen it. It can be a bit tricky.
Just fiddle around, and you'll get it in the end.

405.text:
Once you've extended your boom pole
out to the length that you want it,

408.text:
which will probably
be longer than this,

410.text:
you can attach your mic to your recording
device using a long XLR cable.

415.text:
I'd recommend something
between five and ten metres.

418.text:
I've got one here, so let's
just show you what to do.

423.text:
This is ten metres,
which is quite long.

435.text:
Now cables are a soundman's nightmare.
And here's a good tip…

440.text:
What you should do is put the cable around the
boom pole like this, and then hold it taut,

451.text:
and that's going to stop it flapping against the
boom pole, which your mic is going to pick up.

456.text:
OK, so let me show you
how to hold a boom pole.

460.text:
They're normally held high above your head like
that, although down below is also a viable option.

466.text:
I'm not going to hold it too high, because
you won't be able to see what I'm doing.

469.text:
Hold the foam part of the pole, and have
you hands facing outwards like this.

475.text:
And what you do is you rest the pole here in your
leading hand between the thumb and the forefinger.

481.text:
That way you can easily turn the mic, if you
need to change the way that it's pointing,

486.text:
using your hand here at
the base of the pole.

489.text:
And this hand is also
gripping the wire.

492.text:
I'm just going to move along so that you
can see what's happening at the mic end.

499.text:
When you're using a boom pole, or even when you're
just holding this pistol grip during an interview,

506.text:
you have to be really careful that your
microphone doesn’t appear in shot.

510.text:
You should also be aware of any shadows
cast by your microphone or your boom pole.

514.text:
Making sure your microphone is out
of shot is especially difficult

518.text:
if you're using a big, fluffy
windshield like this one.

523.text:
The NTG2 does come with it's own
foam shield, which I've got here.

528.text:
I'd recommend you use this
when you're shooting indoors,

531.text:
but when you go outdoors,
always change to this one.

534.text:
And this is why. This is sound recorded outside
in moderate wind using the foam shield.

548.text:
And this is sound recorded
using the fluffy windshield.

560.text:
Now I'm just going to show
you how to put them on.

562.text:
It just slips over the microphone like
that. It's really easy. Pull it off.

569.text:
Put the foam one on. There you go.
No trouble at all.

574.text:
This fluffy windshield can be used on the
microphone when it's mounted on your camera,

581.text:
but you do have to be careful
that it doesn't appear in shot,

583.text:
which means you might have to
zoom in a tad to avoid it.

586.text:
If you don't have a boom operator, you could also
use a mic stand or a light stand as an alternative.

592.text:
Of course, a stand is only useful
if you don't have to move around.

596.text:
So let's get rid of our boom
pole… and bring in a stand.

610.text:
This is a mic stand. Now, mic stands and light
stands have different screw attachment sizes.

616.text:
Light stands usually have the same size
screw attachment as the RØDE Boompole,

623.text:
which means you can carry on using
your pistol grip if you want to.

627.text:
Microphone stands, especially tall floor stands
like this one, usually have bigger threads,

632.text:
so you're not going to be
able to use the pistol grip.

634.text:
Instead you're going to have to use
another type of mount. Like this one.

639.text:
Now this is a simple, plastic microphone
mount that actually comes with the NTG2.

644.text:
It fastens on quite easily to
the end of the stand like this.

653.text:
Right, better tighten that up.
There we go.

658.text:
It can be quite difficult to get the
microphone into one of these mounts.

664.text:
But if you angle it like this and
push down, it does clip into place.

669.text:
If you're leaving you mic
on a stand like this,

671.text:
you have to be careful it doesn't
accidentaly get knocked over,

675.text:
so put a sandbag or a similar kind
of weight on the base of the stand.

679.text:
Those were a few ways
of handling the NTG2.

682.text:
Before we move on, there are a few other
important things you need to know about the mic.

687.text:
Firstly, it's a condenser microphone,
which means it needs to be powered.

692.text:
In general, this power's going to come from
your recording device via the XLR cable,

697.text:
and it's something that’s
called phantom power.

699.text:
To use phantom power you need to make sure your
device is set to send power to the microphone.

705.text:
On the JVC, what you have to do is make sure
that this switch here is set to "Mic +48v".

710.text: So I'll do it here on Input 2,

712.text:
and I'm only doing it on Input 2 because
I'm plugged in to Input 2 here.

716.text:
I'll just do that
to the camera.

719.text:
There you go, switch it down to "Mic +48v"
and you're sending power to your mic.

724.text:
Alternatively, the NTG2
can run on battery power.

728.text:
What you need is a 1.5v AA battery,
just a normal battery like this.

733.text:
And it fits into this compartment
at the end of the microphone.

737.text:
There it is, unscrew it, pop the
battery in, screw it back up,

743.text:
and there you go, you don't need phantom
power now from your recording device.

747.text:
Finally, the NTG2 has a switchable
high pass filter, which you can use

752.text:
when you want to get rid of low frequency
sounds such as traffic or air conditioning.

756.text:
I'll show you where it is.
There it is.

759.text:
Now to turn it on, what you need
is a small screwdriver or a pen.

763.text: So I'll show you how to do it.

764.text:
Stick the pen in there
and switch it up.

768.text:
The filter works by blocking
sound frequencies below 80 Hz,

772.text:
and letting higher frequency
sounds pass through.

775.text:
It can affect the tonal characteristics of
your audio, so be very careful when using it.

780.text:
Do a few test recordings
to make sure.

784.text:
So that was the RØDE
NTG2 shotgun microphone.

787.text:
Lets move on now to
the RØDE Lavalier.

790.text:
I'm just going to get everything off the
table, and bring on the RØDE Lavalier.

797.text:
As you can see, it comes
in this useful box.

804.text:
Lavaliers are also known as lavs,
lapel mics, or clip on mics.

809.text:
They're designed to be used during
interviews or dialogue scenes.

813.text:
As you can see, they're
really small microphones,

816.text:
and with this clip they can easily be attached to
a person's clothing, like the one I've got here.

821.text:
This gives you great quality audio because
it's right next to the source of your sound,

825.text: which in this case is my voice.

827.text:
The RØDE Lav has an
omnidirectional polar pattern.

831.text:
As you can see from this diagram, this means
it picks up sound from all directions.

835.text:
As such, you don't have to worry too much about
which direction your microphone is pointing,

840.text:
or about things like slight head movements, that
might change where your sound is coming from.

844.text:
You do have to worry
about getting the mic

846.text:
as close as possible to the
source of your sound, however,

849.text:
otherwise you're going to pick
up a lot of background noise.

852.text:
Setting up and using a
lav is fairly easy.

855.text:
When you first get your RØDE Lav, you may find
that it's seperated out into different parts.

860.text:
So I'm just going to take it apart
here, to show you how to assemble it.

867.text:
What you'll get is this MiCon cable,
then you've got the microphone head,

873.text:
which is tiny, so be really careful
you don't loose it or drop it,

878.text:
Then you've got the
microphone clip,

882.text:
and you've got two different connectors to
connect to different recording devices.

889.text:
Finally, you've got these two different
microphone shields or covers.

894.text:
What you do is you take this MiCon
cable and attach the head to it.

899.text:
You can attach it to either end of
the cable, so that's quite easy.

902.text:
You screw it on
gently like that.

905.text:
Then you need to
choose your adaptor.

907.text:
In this case, I'm going to go with the XLR adaptor,
because I want to plug the lav into the JVC.

916.text:
It's pretty heavy, so you have
to be careful. There we go.

921.text:
Now if I was going to use the lav
with the Zoom audio recorder,

925.text:
I'd be using this connector instead,
which is a minijack connector.

929.text:
The connections on the MiCon cable are quite
delicate, so you do need to be careful.

934.text:
Make sure that the microphone and the
connector are screwed on firmly though,

938.text:
because if you have a loose connection,
you're going to get interference,

941.text:
which is going to
ruin your recording.

943.text:
To attach the clip, what you do is
you hold it between two fingers,

948.text:
and then you press down
on this wire loop,

951.text:
and you stick the microphone head
through the loop, and you let go.

955.text:
The microphone has these little grooves on its
body, and that's where the wire should go.

960.text:
And it should hold pretty
firmly in place like that.

963.text:
With the clip on this side, the microphone
is going to attach to this side of my body.

970.text:
To have it on the other side, what you need to do is
take it off, turn it upside down, and put it on again.

978.text:
And there you go, it's going to
attach to this side of my body.

982.text:
Finally, you've got these
two microphone shields.

985.text:
This one here is
called a pop filter,

988.text:
and I'd recommend you use it at
all times when recording indoors.

990.text:
It helps prevent the popping sound
you get when you say "p"s and "t"s.

995.text:
This furry one here is called a mini furry, and
it's for use outdoors to prevent wind noise.

1001.text:
Both of them fit very
snugly onto the microphone.

1004.text:
What you do is you just push them on
like that, you see. And take it off.

1009.text:
Be very careful when your doing that with the
pop filter because it is quite delicate.

1014.text:
I'll just show you
what this looks like.

1017.text:
It's quite obvious. It does make the microphone more
obvious, but you do have to prevent wind noise.

1023.text:
So, now you've got your microphone set up
you're ready to attach it to your subject.

1029.text:
Where you position your mic is
actually really important.

1032.text:
The best position is in the centre of the chest
about six to eight inches below the subject's chin.

1038.text:
You don't want to get it too high because you'll find
that the sound is blocked by the subject's chin,

1043.text:
and it's easy to pick up
unwanted noises like breathing.

1046.text:
The clothing your subject is wearing will often
dictate exactly where you clip the mic on.

1051.text:
In between buttons on a shirt, or the edge of a
jacket like this is going to work really well.

1056.text:
Now you need to make sure that the mic isn't
going to be rubbing against anything.

1060.text:
That's why it's attached to the outside
of your clothing like this one.

1063.text:
And that's also why the microphone is
lifted a little bit above the clip.

1068.text:
Wherever you position your mic, you need to
do a sound test before you start recording

1072.text:
to make sure you're getting a signal that
is as strong and clear as possible.

1077.text:
If you hear any unwanted noises, you
need to take action to eliminate them.

1081.text:
For instance, if you're getting
rustling from your subject's clothing,

1084.text:
you may have to ask
them to change it.

1086.text:
And if the hair of your subject is
brushing against the top of the mic,

1090.text:
you're going to have
to put their hair up.

1092.text:
More importantly than anything, you need
to make sure that your subject knows

1095.text:
not to touch or move the
microphone during the recording.

1101.text:
you need to make sure that you do
everything you can to hide the cable.

1105.text:
You could, for instance, thread it inside the
shirt, or tape it to the inside of the jacket.

1110.text:
A visible cable really does look quite
bad, so do what you can to hide it.

1115.text:
Now there's just one more thing I need
to cover about using the Lavalier,

1118.text:
and that's how to connect it
up to your recording device.

1121.text:
In this case my recording device
is the JVC, which I've got here.

1129.text:
Now, to connect the mic up to the JVC you
need an XLR cable, and I've got one here.

1138.text:
So you take the female end of the XLR cable
and you plug it into the connector here.

1146.text:
Then you can make use of this very useful
clip and place these connectors out of sight

1155.text:
by clipping them onto the belt of your
subject or maybe onto the back pocket.

1160.text:
Then you can take the other end of the
XLR cable, and plug it into your JVC.

1167.text:
I'm using Input 1 here. I'll show
you to camera. There you go.

1173.text:
Now, with this set-up, you've got a cable that's
running between your camera and your subject.

1180.text:
So it's more suited to things like sit down
interviews and stationary pieces to camera.

1185.text:
Do be careful, of course, that no-one
is going to trip over the cable.

1190.text:
Unlike the shotgun mic, this lavalier
does not need to be powered,

1194.text:
so you need to go back to the
input switches here on the JVC,

1198.text:
and you need to make sure that Input
1, which is where I'm plugged in,

1206.text:
So lets just do that.
There you go.

1209.text:
That means that the camera is not going
to send any power to the microphone.

1213.text:
As I've already mentioned, you can also use the
lav in conjunction with the Zoom audio recorder.

1218.text:
All you need to do is
change the connector.

1222.text:
So let's unplug it.
Take it off gently.

1228.text:
And we're going to put
on this mini jack.

1236.text:
Let's get rid of all this,
and bring on the Zoom.

1242.text:
Now, the mini-jack connects up to the Zoom
here where it says line in. Let's plug it in.

1250.text:
Using the lav with the Zoom
makes you effectively wireless,

1254.text:
because you're recording onto the Zoom and you can
put it in your pocket and walk around with it.

1258.text:
This gives you a lot more mobility
and you can do things like

1261.text:
allow your subject to walk down the street

1265.text:
It also allows you to be more creative
in how you use the microphone.

1269.text:
Although not ideal, it doesn't have to be
just used as a clip-on interview mic,

1274.text:
it could also be
used in other ways.

1275.text:
For instance, you could put it on the table and
record the conversation between two or more people,

1280.text:
or you could hide it in the scenery
to record more general sound.

1284.text:
However, do bear in mind that when
you're recording onto the Zoom,

1288.text:
you're going to have to sync your audio
up with the visuals when you're editing,

1292.text:
which does add another
layer of work.

1295.text:
I'm going to talk more about the Zoom and

1298.text:
If you want to skip through to that section
now, you can use the button beside me.

1303.text:
Both the mics I've just covered, the NTG2 shotgun and
the Lavalier, are quite versatile in their uses.

1310.text:
Now I'm going to look at a mic
that has a more specific use:

1315.text:
Now, this mic is designed to be used with
a DSLR camera, like this one, the 700D.

1321.text: DSLRs are mainly for taking photos. Video is really only just an add on.

1326.text:
Although you can get some lovely footage out of
them, recording good audio is more problematic.

1331.text:
They do have their own
in-built microphones.

1334.text:
You can see this is the microphone
here on the 700D. It's very small.

1338.text:
The quality of these microphones is very low, and
they're really more for reference than anything else.

1345.text:
The VideoMic Pro aims to overcome this
limitation, at least to some degree.

1350.text:
The audio it captures isn't as
good as the NTG2 for instance,

1354.text:
but this mic more than makes up for
it's relative lack in quality

1357.text:
by being super convenient
and easy to use.

1360.text:
Indeed, in auto mode, all you really need to do is
attach it to the camera, plug it in, and turn it on.

1367.text:
all of a sudden the audio capabilities of
your DSLR camera have jumped a hundred fold,

1371.text:
without much in the way of
additional gear burden.

1374.text:
So it's a solid fallback if you can't manage the hassle
of recording your audio onto a separate device,

1380.text:
which is what you really have to do if
you want to get good quality sound

1386.text:
Like the NTG2, the VideoMic
Pro is a shotgun mic

1390.text:
with a narrow supercardiod polar pattern,
which targets sounds directly in front.

1395.text:
This is one of the reasons it
captures such good audio,

1398.text:
because it focuses on the
sound that you want,

1400.text:
and rejects noise from the
surrounding environment.

1403.text:
It's also a condenser mic, which
means it needs to be powered.

1406.text:
Now, DSLRs don't supply phantom power, so
this mic powers itself using a 9v battery.

1412.text:
The battery fits in here, and it can be really
difficult to remove this cover and get it out,

1418.text:
so don't do it unless
you really need to.

1420.text:
And you won't need to often because it gives
you about 70 hours of operating time.

1426.text:
The mic comes cradled in its
own intergrated shock mount,

1429.text:
which is another reason it can
capture such good audio,

1432.text:
because you're not going to get handling
noises from operating the camera.

1436.text:
At the base of the mount you
can see there's an attachment

1439.text:
for the hotshoe on the
top of your DSLR camera.

1441.text:
And that’s in general
where it's put.

1444.text:
There's also a thread here for attaching
to a boom pole or a stand, but to do that,

1449.text:
what you'd need to do is extend this existing cable
with another audio cable, which isn't supplied.

1456.text:
To attach the mic to the camera, all you need
to do is slip it in to the hotshoe here,

1463.text:
and tighten up this
ring, so it's secure.

1466.text:
Then you need to attach
the audio cable.

1469.text:
You attach it here. It says mic on the
flap, so it's pretty easy to find.

1476.text:
You open it up and
then you plug it in.

1482.text:
There you go. All
nicely attached now.

1485.text:
Now, you have to turn the microphone on, which
you do at the back here, using the top switch.

1491.text:
Be careful when you're pushing the
switch over not to push it all the way,

1495.text:
but only push it into the middle
where you can see the straight line.

1499.text:
When you push it over, you can
see the green light turn on.

1503.text:
If you're going to push it all the way to the
other side where you can see that angled line,

1508.text:
what you're doing is activating
the mic's high-pass filter,

1511.text:
which I'll talk a bit
more about in a minute.

1515.text:
Forgetting to turn this microphone
on is a really common mistake.

1519.text:
I know I've done it
a few times myself.

1521.text:
It's very frustrating, because when you
do that you don't get any audio at all,

1525.text:
not even from the camera's
in-built microphone,

1528.text:
because that's automatically disabled
when the VideoMic is plugged in.

1533.text:
Just try to make a habit of keeping a look out for
the green light on the back of the microphone.

1539.text:
The high-pass filter I just mentioned works
in the same way as the filter on the NTG2.

1544.text:
It cuts out low-frequency sounds below 80 Hz,
such as the rumble of traffic in the distance.

1551.text:
Again, be very careful about using the filter,
because it can make your audio sound funny,

1556.text:
so do a few tests before
you decide to use it.

1559.text:
Below this switch there's another switch, which
acts to either boost or reduce the audio signal

1564.text:
that the microphone is
sending to the camera.

1567.text:
At the moment it's on 0 dB, or zero decibels,
and that's basically the off position.

1572.text:
If I were to switch
it down to -10 dB,

1575.text:
what we'd be doing is sending a
weaker signal to the camera.

1579.text:
That's especially useful when you're recording in
very loud envionments such as a live music venue.

1585.text:
Then you've got this +20 dB setting, which
sends a stronger signal to the camera.

1591.text:
This is useful not only when
you want to boost volume.

1595.text:
It also helps reduce the hiss that you
commonly get when recording audio on a DSLR.

1600.text:
This trick only works when you're setting
your audio levels manually inside the camera.

1605.text:
With a stronger signal you can
turn your audio levels down,

1609.text:
and this, of course, also
reduces the background hiss,

1612.text:
which is caused by the poor audio
circuitry inside the camera.

1615.text:
Unfortunatly, if you're recording in auto,
which you often have to do with a DSLR,

1621.text:
there's nothing much you
can do about the hiss.

1623.text:
Although I'd always recommend you
set your audio levels manually,

1627.text:
that's often impractical
to do on a DSLR.

1630.text:
And that's because you can't
actually monitor your sound.

1633.text:
There's nowhere to plug in earphones,
which is obviously a major drawback.

1639.text:
it's no surprise that forgetting to turn the
microphone on is such a common mistake.

1643.text:
Another big problem is
things like wind noise.

1646.text:
You can't tell when there's something
going wrong with your audio.

1650.text:
Now, this foam shield
here can't be taken off.

1653.text:
RØDE does make a big fluffy windshield
that fits over it. It's called a Deadcat.

1658.text:
I'd recommend that if you can
get hold of one of those,

1661.text:
you always use it when
you're shooting outdoors.

1663.text:
Without the ability to monitor your sound, your
best option if you're out and about shooting,

1669.text:
especially if you're changing locations, is to
leave the camera's audio levels set to auto.

1674.text:
If your shoot is relatively controlled, for
instance if you're filming an interview inside,

1679.text:
or if you are in a classroom and the
level of noise is relatively constant,

1683.text:
I'd say do have a go at setting
the audio levels manually.

1687.text:
To make sure your audio is going to be OK,
do a few test clips before you start,

1691.text:
Then listen to them
back on a computer.

1694.text:
You don't want to use the camera
to listen to what you've recoded,

1697.text:
because the playback speaker, which
is back here, is very poor quality.

1703.text:
But what if you're shooting on a DSLR and
you want to get really good quality audio?

1708.text:
Well, you'd need to record onto an external
device like this one, the Zoom H2n.

1715.text:
Now when you're recording
onto something like this,

1717.text:
your visuals and your audio
are going to be separate,

1720.text:
and you're going to have to put
them together when you're editing.

1723.text: With this kind of dual set-up,

1725.text:
you do have to remember to record some
kind of audio on the DSLR as well.

1729.text:
If you don't do that then you're not
going to have a reference track,

1732.text:
which means that syncing the two together
is going to be really troublesome.

1735.text:
I've already talked a little bit about the Zoom,
but I want to go into it in more depth now.

1740.text:
So let's just get
rid of the DSLR.

1745.text:
The Zoom is a compact and
versatile piece of equipment

1749.text:
that allows you to record high-quality
audio in a variety of different scenarios.

1754.text:
Not only does it let you connect up to an external
microphone, it also has its own microphones.

1759.text:
Five capsules in all, in
fact, behind this mesh.

1762.text:
And that gives you four
different record modes.

1764.text:
It's very easy to use, but it
does have a lot of features.

1768.text:
I'm not going to be able to talk
about all of them in this video,

1770.text:
but I will cover the basics
to get you up and running.

1773.text:
The Zoom runs on 1.5v AA batteries, which you
can access by opening the back like this.

1781.text:
Now, you can use either alkaline
or nickel–metal hydride batteries,

1785.text:
but be sure to set which battery you're
going to be using in the settings menu,

1790.text:
otherwise you won't get an accurate
reading of how much power you have left.

1794.text:
By default, the Zoom
is set to alkaline.

1797.text:
Now, these batteries are going to give
you about 20 hours of operating time,

1804.text:
The Zoom records onto an SD card, which fits
into a slot here at the base of the machine.

1809.text:
You pick open the flap here like
that, and there's the SD card.

1814.text:
Push it in and it
pops out like that.

1817.text:
And if you want to put it back in, you put it in like
that. Push it into place and it clicks into place.

1823.text:
I'll just do that to the camera.
There you go.

1827.text:
Push it in to get it out. It pops out, and
then push it back in and it clicks into place.

1836.text:
The Zoom can take normal SD cards
with a capacity up to 2 GB

1841.text:
as well as high-capacity
cards up to 32 GB.

1845.text:
Audio recordings don't
take up much space.

1848.text:
To give you an idea, a 32 GB card could
record up to 50 hours of high-quality audio.

1854.text:
So a 2 GB card is normally
going to be enough.

1858.text:
Just be aware though that the maximum file
size of any recording on the Zoom is 2 GB.

1864.text:
This doesn't mean that you
can't record continuously,

1867.text:
it just means that if you go over 2 GB,
more than one file is going to be created.

1872.text:
You turn the Zoom on by flicking this
power switch here down like that.

1880.text:
The screen turns on
as you can see,

1882.text:
and you can check the battery life by looking
at this icon here at the top of the screen.

1887.text:
So let's talk about all
the icons on the screen.

1890.text:
At the top here you've got
all of these numbers,

1893.text:
which are a time indicator telling you how
long each clip has been recorded for.

1897.text:
Next to that you've got
the "Auto Gain" icon,

1900.text:
which is telling you that the Zoom is
setting your audio levels automatically.

1904.text:
I'll tell you how to change that so that you can set
the audio levels yourself a bit later on in the video.

1910.text:
"Auto Gain" is one of the default settings we
recommend in our reset guide for the Zoom,

1915.text:
which can be found
on our website.

1917.text:
They're designed to be printed out and
put in the bag along with the device.

1921.text:
Down below the numbers you've
got the recording mode status,

1924.text:
which tells you which of the four
recording modes you're currently in.

1930.text:
which is also a default setting that
we recommend in our reset guide.

1934.text:
Next to this, you've got the
Side-Level Adjustment,

1937.text:
which is available in all of the
modes apart from XY recoding mode.

1941.text:
I'll to talk about the information that these two
icons represent a little more later on in the video.

1947.text: Let's move on down the screen.

1949.text:
Here you've got your audio meters, which show the
volume at which your sound is being recorded.

1955.text:
There are two bars here and that's because
the Zoom is recording two channels of audio.

1961.text:
Think of these two channels as being for your two
ears, one for the left and one for the right,

1966.text:
hence the "L" and the "R"
that you can see here.

1969.text:
In most of the record modes on the Zoom
you're going to get two channels of audio.

1973.text:
There is one record mode though
that has four channels,

1976.text:
in which case you're going to see
four bars here on the screen.

1979.text:
Below the meter here you can see all of
these numbers. These are your decibels.

1985.text:
Zero is basically the ceiling, and what
you're aiming for is between -12 and -3.

1991.text:
At the end of the meter you can see you've
got two boxes here for each channel.

1995.text:
These boxes are normally
going to be empty of colour.

1998.text:
They turn black when the bars
have hit the top of the meter,

2002.text:
and they're basically a warning that your audio
is too loud and may have clipped or distorted.

2007.text:
Down here at the bottom of the
screen you can see these numbers.

2012.text:
At the moment its set to 48/24,
which is 48 kHz 24 bits.

2018.text:
That's basically the quality
of the audio you're recording.

2021.text:
48/24 is a good high-quality
setting that's suitable for video.

2026.text:
Finally, you've got
this section here.

2029.text:
Now, you can see this SD icon… that means
that you've got an SD card inserted.

2034.text:
The numbers next to it mean the amount of
time you've got left to record onto the card.

2039.text:
If I was to remove the card
all of that would change.

2043.text:
So I've taken it out now, and you can
see the SD icon has turned to an "M",

2051.text:
That means you're going to be recording
onto the internal memory of the device,

2055.text:
which is only going to give you
one minute of record time.

2058.text:
That's very limiting, so we always
recommend that you use an SD card…

2062.text: I'll put it back in now.

2065.text:
So that’s all you're normally going to see on
the screen when you turn it on in record mode.

2071.text:
Let's look at the
body of the Zoom now.

2073.text:
Just here below the screen
you've got the record button,

2076.text:
which you can tell by
this big red dot here.

2079.text:
When you press that and you're recording,
a red light is going to come on here.

2083.text:
Moving to the side
of the device now.

2086.text:
Here you've got the Menu button,
which is used to access the menu.

2090.text:
Below that you've got the Play button,
which you press to play back your clips,

2094.text:
and this is also a jog wheel which is
used to navigate the menu and select.

2099.text:
I'll just show you how that's done by
going into the menu… There you go.

2104.text:
Now I'm going to navigate up
and down with the jog wheel,

2108.text:
and I'm going to
select by pressing in.

2111.text:
I'll just do that to the camera so
you can see how the jog wheel works.

2115.text:
You can press up and down,
and press in to select.

2120.text:
Now, if you want to go back, what you
do is you press the Menu button.

2123.text:
Press it once quickly, and that's going
to take you back to the previous screen.

2128.text:
If you want to go straight back to your home screen,
you have to press and hold the Menu button,

2133.text:
and that will take you
back in one step.

2136.text:
Next you've got the
Mic Gain dial,

2138.text:
which is where you adjust your audio
levels if you're recording in manual.

2143.text:
Turning it down to 0 means
you're going to get no sound,

2147.text:
and 10 is obviously
the loudest setting.

2151.text:
Below that you've got the power
switch, which I've already mentioned.

2155.text:
It does have another
function though.

2157.text:
If you slide it up into "Hold", you're
basically locking all the buttons on the Zoom.

2162.text:
Now this is really useful if you've got it
in your pocket or something like that,

2165.text:
because it means you're not going to accidentally
knock any of the buttons and ruin your recording.

2170.text:
Moving over to the other
side of the unit now.

2173.text:
This is where you plug
in your microphone.

2175.text:
The H2n only has this one 3.5mm
microphone input, which is a limitation.

2182.text:
It means out of all the microphones
that CADARN provides,

2184.text:
it'll only work with the
Videomic and the Lavalier.

2188.text:
You could plug in the NTG2, but you'd
need an XLR-to-minijack converter.

2193.text:
You would also need to put a
battery into the microphone,

2196.text:
because the Zoom does not
supply phantom power.

2199.text:
Below this minijack
you've got your volume.

2201.text:
Now this controls the volume
of the Zoom's output,

2205.text:
which has nothing to do with the level of
the audio that you're actually recording.

2209.text:
It's what you're hearing,
either through your headphones

2211.text:
or through this speaker
here above the screen.

2215.text:
I would recommend that you leave
this volume at a constant level.

2218.text:
If you keep changing it you're not going to be able
to monitor your audio levels very successfully.

2223.text:
Next you've got a little socket here for a remote
control, which you have to purchase seperately.

2229.text:
Moving on down, you've got
another 3.5mm socket,

2233.text:
which is for plugging
in your earphones.

2235.text:
Finally, down here at the bottom
you've got this USB Mini B port,

2240.text:
which is for connecting the
Zoom up to your computer.

2243.text:
This allows you to copy all of
your files over to your computer.

2247.text:
It also allows you to record directly onto the
computer using your prefered audio recording software.

2253.text:
You could also use this USB port
to run the Zoom off the mains,

2257.text:
but for that you'd need an AC
adapter, which is not supplied.

2261.text:
Moving on to the
base of the device,

2263.text:
apart from this SD card slot, you've
also got a standard tripod mount,

2267.text:
which allows you to attach the Zoom
to any tripod or any GorillaPod.

2272.text:
I recommend you do this if you're using
the in-built microphones on the Zoom,

2275.text:
because a tripod or a GorillaPod is going to
help isolate the Zoom from any handling noises.

2281.text:
Finally, up here at the top, what
you've got is a Record Mode dial.

2286.text:
This makes it really easy to select which of the
in-built microphones you're going to use, and how.

2291.text:
As I've already mentioned, the
five in-built microphones

2294.text:
give us four different record
modes for different scenarios.

2298.text:
The five microphones fall
into two basic types.

2300.text:
First you've got the XY
microphones at the front here,

2304.text:
and then you've got the MS
microphones at the back.

2307.text:
There are two surround sound modes, which record
either two channels or four channels of audio.

2314.text:
Now, these two modes engage both the XY
and the MS microphones at the same time,

2323.text:
So let's look at all of these record modes in a bit
more detail, and I'm going to start with the XY mode.

2329.text:
Let's turn the dial to point to XY. As you can see,
this light has turned off and this one has stayed on,

2337.text:
because I'm only activating the
XY microphones at the front here.

2340.text:
This mode uses two different microphones
pointing in different directions.

2345.text:
You've got the right mic, which is pointing left
like that, and the left mic which is pointing right.

2350.text:
And there's an 90-degree
space between them.

2353.text:
This creates an overlapping polar pattern,
which you can see from this diagram.

2358.text:
This is going to give you
a fuller stereo sound

2360.text:
that's less spacey than a normal
stereo recording would be.

2364.text:
It's particularly useful if you're
recording nearby sound sources

2368.text:
like an interview or a
simple musical performance.

2371.text:
Just one note though. Do be careful to keep
the device pointing in the right direction.

2376.text:
The mics are on this side so this is the way it
should be pointing, towards your sound source.

2380.text:
On the other side of the Zoom
you've got your three MS mics.

2384.text:
Let's just turn the dial
so it's pointing to them.

2388.text:
MS stands for Mid/Side, and you can see
from this diagram what that means.

2394.text:
The mid microphone is a front
facing directional microphone

2398.text:
for picking up your main source
of sound, such as dialogue.

2401.text: The two side microphones are for picking up sound to the left and to the right,

2405.text:
which add ambience
to your recording.

2407.text:
Now this is a very versatile mode and you can
even change the range of your side microphones,

2413.text:
which you do using
the play wheel here.

2416.text:
I'll just show you what happens
when I start moving it up and down.

2419.text:
There, you can see a
diagram comes up.

2421.text:
If I move it down, the size of these
polar patterns is decreasing,

2427.text:
which means the range
is decreasing.

2430.text:
And if I was going to turn
it up, it would get bigger.

2434.text:
If I went all the way to the top,
I get to something called RAW.

2439.text:
What RAW does is seperate
the two channels

2442.text:
so that you can actually decide
on the mix when you're editing.

2446.text:
Finally, you've got the two surround sound modes,
which I've already talked about a little bit.

2451.text:
Let's turn it back to the
two-channel setting now.

2454.text:
As you can see, the two lights come on because
I'm using the microphones on both sides.

2460.text:
As I'm still using the MS microphones, I can
still set the range of the side microphones

2466.text:
as I did before using the
play toggle like that.

2471.text:
When it's in two-channel mode, everything's combined
into one file and recorded onto your SD card.

2477.text:
If, however, you're in four-channel
mode, it's going to record two files,

2483.text:
and you have the freedom then to put those
together and mix them as you wish in your editing.

2488.text:
As you already know, the Zoom can also
record from an external microphone,

2492.text:
and I've got the Lavalier
here as an example.

2497.text: Now to record from just this microphone, you need to be in XY mode.

2501.text: So I'll turn to XY here.

2503.text:
When the plug is in, a little message
appears on the screen saying external in,

2508.text:
and as you can see there
is also a new icon there.

2511.text:
The other thing you have to do to use an external
mic is make sure that "Plug-in Power" is turned on.

2517.text:
And to do that you need
to go into the menus.

2519.text:
So let's just check that it is turned on. Press
the Menu button. Scroll down to "Input",

2529.text:
then you need to scroll down to
"Plug-In Power", which is there.

2534.text:
And it was turned off, so it's
a good thing that we checked.

2539.text:
There we go. Now I'm going to hold the
Menu button to go back to my home screen.

2544.text:
In this mode, with the external mic attached,
the XY microphones are actually disabled.

2550.text:
If you were to turn to two-channel or
four-channel surround sound, however,

2554.text:
what you'd be able to do is
record from two sources,

2557.text:
the external mic and the MS
microphones at the back here.

2561.text:
This is particulary useful if you're doing
something like recording a presentation

2565.text:
where you've got one main speaker but you don't
want to miss any comments from the audience.

2570.text:
It is worth noting that if
you were to turn to MS mode,

2574.text:
you wouldn't be able to record from
the external microphone at all,

2577.text:
and a little message does appear
on the screen to tell you that.

2582.text:
So, we've looked at the
basic anatomy of the Zoom,

2584.text:
and we've looked at what
normally appears on the screen,

2587.text:
and we've also looked at the four
recording modes that are available.

2591.text:
Now you're finally ready
to start recording.

2598.text:
Now, to start recording you
press the record button here.

2602.text:
When you do that the red light appears
and things change on the screen.

2605.text:
First of all you've got the record icon there, and
then you've got the name of the file you're creating.

2611.text:
Above that you've got the counters counting up, which
is telling you how long you've been recording.

2616.text:
And down here in the corner the
counter is counting down,

2619.text:
because you've got less and
less time on your SD card.

2623.text:
To stop recording, you press the record button
again and the screen returns to normal.

2629.text:
To listen to your recordings, you
need to use the play button here.

2632.text: What you do is you press it in,

2634.text:
and your clips are going to start playing
starting from the last one you recorded.

2638.text:
So let's give that a go. Press it in…
there… my clip has just started playing.

2645.text:
I'll just press it
again to pause it.

2647.text:
If I want to skip through my clips I can do that
with the toggle function on the Play button.

2652.text:
I'm skipping down now. To play that clip that I've
just selected, I press in again and it starts playing.

2662.text: Press in again to pause it.

2664.text:
If you press the Menu button while you're in playback
mode, you're going to get the Playback Menu.

2669.text:
So let's just do that.
There you go.

2671.text:
Now, I'm not going to cover
this menu in any depth,

2675.text:
but it is worth saying that you can adjust
the speed and the pitch of your recording,

2680.text:
which is very useful if you're doing
something like transcribing an interview.

2685.text:
You can also do some basic
editing on your clips.

2688.text:
To get out of playback mode, all you need to
do is press the Menu button and hold it in,

2693.text:
and it's going to return you to your
home screen or your recording screen.

2698.text:
Now we're back to the home screen, let's
talk about the main menu on the Zoom.

2702.text:
I'm not going to go into it in very much detail, but
there are two core things that I want to show you.

2708.text:
Firstly, how to change the format of
the audio file that you're recording,

2712.text:
because there is
quite a wide range.

2714.text:
So, let's press the menu
button to get into the menu.

2722.text:
Press in to select and then press
in again to select "Record Format".

2728.text:
We recommend that you
record in WAV format,

2730.text:
because that is going to
give you uncompressed audio.

2733.text:
As I've already mentioned 48 kHz at 24 bits
is going to give you really great quality,

2738.text:
but the file sizes
are quite large.

2741.text:
The Zoom also records in
various flavours of MP3.

2745.text:
Now those are smaller files, but it is compressed
audio so the quality isn't going to be as good.

2751.text:
The other thing I want to show you
is how to turn "Auto Gain" off,

2754.text:
so let's get back to our home screen
by holding in the Menu button.

2760.text:
Now I'm back. Let's get
back into the menu.

2764.text:
I want to scroll up to "Input". Press in
to select, and scroll down to "Auto Gain".

2773.text:
Now you need to select "Off", and
there you go, it's turned off.

2778.text:
Let's get back to the
home screen again.

2781.text:
You can see that the "Auto Gain" icon
has disappeared from the corner here.

2786.text:
Now you're in manual, which means you are
in control of the Zoom's audio levels,

2791.text:
which you can adjust using
the Mic Gain dial here.

2795.text: Let's just give it a go.

2797.text:
I'm in MS mode, which means the Zoom is going
to pick up my voice, which is what I want,

2801.text:
and I'm just going to
try and adjust it.

2804.text:
What I want to do is bring it to -12 dB.
It's too low now. I'm turning it up.

2813.text:
There you go, it's hitting… Yes, that's
just about right. It's between -12 and -3,

2819.text:
and you want to be careful, of course,
not to hit the top of the meter.

2823.text:
Once you've turned "Auto Gain" off, there are two
more things you can do to control your levels,

2829.text:
and you have to go back to "Input" in the
menu to get to them, so let's just do that.

2838.text:
The first is "Lo Cut". "Lo Cut" is a
filter similar to the one on the NTG2.

2844.text:
It cuts out low-frequency
sounds such as wind noise.

2847.text: I'd recommend you keep that off.

2853.text:
The selections within this menu allow you
to either compress or limit your sound.

2858.text:
Compression makes sure that your
audio stays within certain limits,

2863.text:
so it boosts your quiet sounds,
and it lowers your loud sounds.

2867.text:
This is particularly useful if you've got a
sound with a very wide range, such as drums.

2872.text:
A limiter makes sure that your sound stays under
a certain threshold so that it doesn't distort.

2877.text:
This is useful if you're recording
something like a live concert

2881.text:
when the music might
get particularly loud.

2883.text:
I'll leave you to explore the
rest of the menu by yourself.

2886.text:
It's very intuitive and if you use our
reset guide you can't go far wrong.

2891.text:
So that's the Zoom
audio recorder.

2894.text:
Let's move on to our final
item now, the RØDE Podcaster.

2900.text:
The RØDE is a good solid microphone designed
for recording straight onto a computer.

2906.text:
You do need audio recording software installed on
your computer, but they all do come with this.

2911.text:
As an alternative, you could
download Audacity for free.

2915.text:
So let's just get rid
of the Zoom now.

2919.text:
The Podcaster is perfect for things like voice-over
for video, radio, or of course podcasts.

2926.text:
Despite the way it looks, it's not meant to be hand
held, in fact it's quite sensitive to handling noise.

2931.text:
It needs to be mounted, which you do
here at the base of the microphone.

2935.text:
So I'm just going to get the mount…
and I've got a stand here as well.

2942.text:
This ring mount actually
comes with the Podcaster,

2946.text:
and to attach it you need to
remove this ring and put it on.

2952.text:
It can be a little bit tricky to
attach, but you get there in the end.

2958.text:
Tighten it up. Everything
has to be nice and tight.

2961.text:
Now, this is a very versatile
mount because it can be attached

2964.text:
to either a microphone stand or a light
stand, thanks to this screw adapter here.

2969.text: I'm just going to put that in.

2973.text:
Having a penny around does help if you want
to tighten it or when you're getting it out.

2980.text: There you go, nice and tight.

2983.text:
Now I'm going to attach
it to this table stand,

2985.text:
which is a very useful thing to have
around if you can get hold of one.

2989.text:
I'm just going to attach it. Better
to have the legs in to do that.

3002.text:
Everything has to
be nice and tight.

3004.text: Open out the legs… There we go.

3009.text:
Now, that's going to work really well
on your desk next to your computer.

3013.text:
The Podcaster has a
cardioid polar pattern,

3016.text:
which means it picks up sound from the end and
from the sides, as you can see from this diagram.

3021.text:
However, to get the best results you really
need to speak into the end like this.

3026.text:
Get as close as you can and don't worry about
the popping sound that some microphones pick up

3030.text:
when you say "t"s and "p"s, because the
Podcaster has an in-built pop filter.

3036.text:
To attach the microphone to a computer you
need to get the USB cord that's supplied

3040.text:
and plug it in here at the
base of the microphone.

3043.text:
That's another reason why the Podcaster
needs to be mounted like this,

3047.text:
because you can't
stand it on its end.

3049.text:
So, I'll just get the USB cord.
Here it is.

3053.text:
You get the fat end of the cord and
you plug it into the base like so.

3061.text:
Then, obviously, the other
end goes into your computer.

3064.text:
The microphone is bus powered, which means
the computer is going to supply its power,

3069.text:
and when you've plugged it in what should
happen is the light at the end here…

3073.text:
it's a green light… comes on. Then you
know the microphone is being powered.

3077.text:
The only other thing I need to
tell you about is this jack here.

3081.text:
It's for attaching your headphones so that
you can monitor your sound in real time.

3086.text:
The dial on the side here is for changing
the volume of what you're hearing.

3090.text:
It has no affect at all on the volume or
the level of the audio you're recording.

3094.text:
You can only control that through
the software on your computer,

3097.text:
which also controls the format
of the file you're recording.

3102.text:
So that's all the core audio
equipment offered by CADARN.

3106.text:
It's a good range of mics and devices that
will meet most if not all of your audio needs,

3112.text:
from high quality on-location sound
recording to in-office podcasting.

3117.text:
Getting good quality audio is really important
for the production of educational media,

3122.text:
indeed it's essential for every
type of media production.

3126.text:
With this gear and
a bit of practice,

3128.text:
I'm sure you'll have no trouble achieving
the high quality that you need.

3133.text:
That's all from me, thanks for
watching, and bye for now.
